Technical Assistance Report 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Project Number: 47938  
Regional Capacity Development Technical Assistance (R-CDTA) 
December 2013 
 
 
 
Promoting Financial Inclusion and Stability in ADB’s 
Transition Member Countries  
 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  GDP  –  gross domestic product 
  SMEs  –  small and medium-sized enterprises 
  PSOD  –  Private Sector Operations Department 
  QFI  –  qualified financial institution 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Regional—capacity development technical assistance (R-CDTA) 
Targeting  –  General intervention 
classification 
Sector (subsector)  –  Finance (industry and trade) 
Themes  –  Private sector development, economic growth, governance, 
capacity development  
Location (impact)  –  Rural (medium), urban (medium), national (medium) 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
Vice-President  L. Venkatachalam, Private Sector and Cofinancing Operations 
Director General  T. Freeland, Private Sector Operations Department (PSOD) 
Director  C. Engstrom, Private Sector Financial Institutions Division, PSOD 
   
Team leader  R. Hartel, Principal Investment Specialist, PSOD 
Team members  P. Flegler, Investment Specialist, PSOD 
  M. Greenhow, Senior Counsel, PSOD 
  M. Hermans, Investment Specialist, PSOD  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

CONTENTS 
Page 
I.  INTRODUCTION  1 
II. ISSUES 1 
III. THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 3 
A. Impact and Outcome  3 
B. Methodology and Key Activities  3 
C. Cost and Financing  4 
D. Implementation Arrangements  4 
IV. THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 4 
APPENDIXES 
1. Design and Monitoring Framework  5 
2. Cost Estimates and Financing Plan   6 
3. Outline Terms of Reference for Consultants   7

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) ranks finance sector development and financial 
inclusion  through  the  involvement  of  private  financial  institutions  high  in  its  Strategy  2020 
agenda and in country programs and strategies for its Central Asian and South Caucasus 
developing member countries.1 Clients of financial institutions and enterprises are important 
generators of employment and producers of goods and services. Financial inclusion also ranks 
high on the strategic agenda for most of these countries, given the very low access to finance. 
The regional technical assistance (TA) for promoting financial inclusion and stability in ADB’s 
transition member countries will support these goals. The design and monitoring framework is in 
Appendix 1.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  ADB sovereign operations in Central Asian and South Caucasus developing member 
countries  (transition  economies)  have  focused  on  improving  the  institutional,  legal,  and 
regulatory framework of the finance sector through loans and TA.3 Private sector operations 
have focused on supporting the finance sector through credit lines, mainly to small and medium-
sized enterprises (SMEs) and rural beneficiaries.  
 
3.  After more than 2 decades of transition from planned to market-based systems, the 
finance sectors in the transition economies are still characterized by high volatility to external 
shocks and challenging corporate governance issues that emerged due to a legal and power 
vacuum during the early years of transition. Most importantly, private enterprise activity—an 
important  provider  of  employment  and  income—is  subdued  as  a  result  of  the  challenging 
business climate and low or costly access to capital.  
 
4.  Since 2008, the global financial crisis has adversely affected the fragile finance sectors, 
resulting in growing relevance and demand for ADB nonsovereign TA and training as an integral 
component of ADB investment support to the nascent private sector. Growth of commercial 
loans has contracted, reducing the already low coverage of the finance sector in depth and 
outreach. For example, the average private sector loan–gross domestic product (GDP) ratio 
remains less than 30% in ADB transition economies, far below other developing economies, 
which averaged 38% in 2012.4 The 2008 crisis and its aftermath highlighted risks associated 
with  excessive  reliance  on  funding  in  foreign  currency,  asset-to-liability  maturity  mismatch 
problems,  inadequate  risk  management,  and  ineffective  regulation  and  supervision.  For 
example, nonperforming loans in Kazakhstan are reportedly high at 30% of gross loans (as of 
October 2013), reflecting the high foreign exchange exposure of the banks’ borrowers and 
resulting in massive defaults when the local currency depreciated during the crisis.5 
 
5.  Access to finance remains a barrier to sustainable and inclusive economic growth in the 
transition economies, and is generally ranked among the most important obstacles to doing 
business. The lack of developed financial markets, as measured by several indicators in recent 
                                                
1  ADB. 2008. Strategy 2020: The Long-Term Strategic Framework of the Asian Development Bank, 2008–2020. 
Manila. 
2  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 24 December 2013. 
3  ADB member countries covered by this TA are Armenia, Azerbaijan, Georgia, Kazakhstan, the Kyrgyz Republic, 
Mongolia, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, and Uzbekistan. Currently ADB’s sovereign operations have ongoing financial 
intermediation loans support funding constraints in Armenia, Kazakhstan, Tajikistan, and Uzbekistan. 
4  International Monetary Fund. 2013. Middle East, North Africa and Central Asia Regional Update. Washington, DC. 
5  The National Bank of Kazakhstan indicates that these nonperforming loans were fully provisioned as of October 
2013.

2 
international reports, is considered a significant competitive  disadvantage.6 Although banks 
generally dominate the finance sector, the penetration of most banking systems is low. The 
transition economies’ banks had less than 70 ATMs per 100,000 adult population in 2012, far 
below the Russian benchmark of 182.7 The countries’ capital markets also remain small. Stock 
market  capitalization  is  only  1.6%  of  GDP  in  Armenia  and  the  Kyrgyz  Republic.  While 
governments and regulatory bodies can address many of the policy, legal, and regulatory issues 
constraining  capital  market  development  with  ADB  sovereign  support, 8  private  financial 
institutions  need  nonsovereign  TA  to  diversify  their  risks  and  develop  their  capabilities  as 
competitive service providers, and to build capacity to ensure they are ready to participate in 
capital market financing as this sector develops.  
6. Strengthening financial infrastructure and increasing access to finance are high on the
development agenda of the transition economies. Despite their differing stages of development, 
the common emphasis has been on developing banking, creating wholesale payment systems, 
and implementing accounting and auditing rules for large firms. Progress has been significant, 
but the distortions that remain impede sector growth. In  addition, loan portfolios are often 
concentrated  in  a  few  sectors,  and  nonbank  financial  institutions  have  a  restricted  role. 
Opportunities for savings remain limited and are often viewed as risky. SMEs and farmers have 
limited  access  to  finance.  Home  loans  are  typically  short  in  tenor  and  expensive.  Legal 
enforcement, governance, and transparency are often weak. These challenges need to be 
addressed. 
7. Lack  of  strategic  focus  and  capacity  limits  the  opportunities  for  private  financial
institutions in the region to facilitate greater access to finance. Corporate skills and leadership in 
financial institutions play an important role in addressing challenges and leading by example in 
the transition economies. Financial institution leaders can promote good practices to improve 
outreach, offer better services, and generate consumer confidence through effective marketing, 
improved  products,  and  responsible  finance  policies.  However,  many  financial  institutions 
operating in the transition economies are influenced by their owners and management by post-
Soviet style and practices that do not conform to international standards of good governance, 
which results in low public trust in the financial system. 
8. While  sovereign  support  for  finance  sector  reforms  has  translated  into  laws  and
regulations that promote good practice, these often have not led to greater borrower access to 
the right type of credit (in terms of tenor, currency, and interest rate base), to credit that is fairly 
priced to reflect risk following sound market principles, or to increased opportunities for savers 
and investors. Most nonsovereign interventions have been made almost exclusively through 
investment financing (credit lines and guarantees) and equity participation. ADB experience 
highlights the need to provide additional TA support to involve existing and prospective ADB 
private financial institution clients in formulating business strategies, operational policies, and 
governance. The TA will help address issues in a solution-focused dialogue with these clients. 
6 World Economic Forum. 2013. Global Competitiveness Report 2012–2013. Geneva; World Bank and International 
Finance Corporation. 2013. Doing Business 2014. Washington, DC. 
7 International Monetary Fund. Access to Finance Database. http://fas.imf.org (accessed 20 November 2013). 
8 ADB. 2010. Technical Assistance for Financial Sector Development in Central and West Asia. Manila.

3 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The impact of the TA will be improved performance of qualified financial institutions 
(QFIs).  Indicators  to  track  this  will  include  accounting  and  reporting  practices  that  match 
International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) as well as requirements of central banks. 
 
10.  The outcome of the TA will be improved institutional policies and financial products of 
QFIs. The TA will address constraints faced by QFIs with regards to product and market 
development, and contribute to enhancing the quality of ADB non-sovereign financial sector 
interventions.  Performance  will  be  measured  in  terms  of  keys  areas  that  reflect  improved 
banking services and prudential requirements. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The TA will improve the capacity of QFIs in transition economies to provide competitive 
services to underserved customers and sectors, and will provide solutions to the constraints 
they face. It will address corporate governance and risk issues, and establish synergies with 
other ADB operations. This will be accomplished through one or a combination of the following 
measures in QFIs targeted by the Financial Institutions Division (PSFI) of ADB’s Private Sector 
Operations  Department  (PSOD):  (i)  well-targeted  institutional  diagnostics;  
(ii) customized solutions for strategy, system, and product development; and (iii) related training 
and capacity building. 
 
12.  The  outputs  will  include  (i)  institutional  diagnostics  of  issues  to  be  addressed;  
(ii)  identification  of  solutions  in  a  consultative  process  involving  QFI  management,  TA 
consultants, and ADB; and (iii) preparation of product- and topic-focused implementation plans 
including the development and testing of new products, and outreach (including branch and 
branchless banking solutions, risk management, corporate governance and controls, as well as 
financial literacy measures); and (iv) execution and supervision of the plans. The outputs will be 
accomplished through training and capacity building. Areas that may be addressed include 
corporate  governance,  risk  management,  introduction  to  Basel  II  and  III  standards,  and 
responsible  finance  policies.  Other  areas  are  product  solutions  for  local  currency  finance; 
microfinance; and housing, SME, and rural finance. Products may include innovative modalities 
to support SME financing; microfinance and insurance; and debt instruments (long-term local 
currency finance); as well as products that create synergies with other sectors such as urban 
services, energy, and transport.9  
 
13.  After completion of the measures carried out by the QFIs, the TA will support regional 
seminars to share the TA experiences and results, and receive feedback for possible future 
interventions. Training programs will be held in host institutions throughout the region, as well as 
in  other  facilities  as  needed.  The  TA  will  fund  travel  expenses  of  resource  persons. 
Representatives from the QFIs and additional eligible participants will pay for their own travel 
costs and related expenses.  
 
                                                
9  Examples may include energy efficiency, renewable energy, and housing finance.

4   
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,154,000, of which $750,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis  by  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF-V).  The  remaining  cost  will  be 
directly funded by the QFIs as stipulated in TA agreements with ADB. The cost estimates and 
financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  ADB will identify and select the QFIs based on the following criteria: 
(i)  The QFI should be a regulated financial institution and the target of an ADB 
nonsovereign investment, including existing and anticipated investments. 
(ii)  The QFI’s top management should be committed to conducting innovations in its 
business that are scalable and able to have a demonstration effect on private 
financial institutions in transition economies. 
(iii)  The QFI’s management has put in place a project team and agrees to share up 
to 35% of the TA cost. 
(iv)  The QFI has or is willing to put in place policies supporting ADB efforts to 
promote good governance, combat money laundering, and ensure environmental 
and social safeguards. 
(v)  ADB is satisfied with the integrity due diligence carried out on the QFI. 
(vi)  PSOD is satisfied with the design of the support in the context of existing and 
anticipated financial institution transactions. 
     
16.  ADB will be the executing agency for the TA, with PSFI acting as the focal point. ADB 
will administer the TA; it may delegate parts of the TA to selected QFIs in compliance with ADB 
procedures and after consultation with ADB’s Operations Services and Financial Management 
Department. Once identified, the QFIs and PSOD will confirm in a TA agreement letter the 
customized  terms  of  reference,  detailed  cost  and  financing  arrangements,  and  consultant 
selection in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended 
from  time  to  time).  Disbursements  will  be  made  in  accordance  with  the  ADB  Technical 
Assistance  Disbursement  Handbook  (2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  Prior  to  the 
commencement of services, ADB will obtain the host country’s no objection to the TA activities. 
TA implementation will begin in January 2014 and be completed by December 2017. The 
outline terms of reference for consultants are provided in Appendix 3. 
 
17.  To  ensure  complementarity,  PSFI  will  work  closely  on  relevant  issues  with  other 
divisions within PSOD, and with ADB’s Central and West Asia and East Asia financial sector, 
public management, and trade divisions; the Treasury Department; and the Office of Risk 
Management. ADB-funded inputs will include about 18 person-months of consulting services. 
The selection method will be determined for each intervention in agreement with the QFI after 
consultation with ADB’s Operations Services and Financial Management Department.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $750,000 on a grant basis to 
selected qualified financial institutions for Promoting Financial Inclusion and Stability in ADB’s 
Transition Member Countries, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Note:  The  technical  assistance  (TA)  is  estimated  to  cost  $1,154,000,  of  which  contributions  from  the  Asian 
Development Bank and qualified financial institutions (QFIs) are presented in the table above. The QFIs will provide 
counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office and housing accommodation, office supplies, domestic 
transportation, and other in-kind contributions. The value of the QFIs’ contribution including parallel financing is 
estimated to account for 35% of the total TA cost. 
a Financed by the Asian Development Bank’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-V). 
b  The QFIs will provide parallel financing or in-kind contributions. Details will be stipulated in TA agreements. 
Source: Asian Development Bank estimates.

Appendix 3  7 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will be delivered in collaboration with qualified financial 
institutions (QFIs) in transition member countries of the Asian Development Bank (ADB).11 ADB 
will select the QFIs based on their capacity building needs and the potential of such measures 
to demonstrate finance sector innovation or enhancements. Upon ADB Management approval, 
the QFIs and ADB will enter into TA agreements that set out the terms and conditions for the 
assistance including the specific terms of reference, the expertise (national and local) required, 
cost, cost sharing, and selection method. The assignments will be posted on ADB’s website as 
business opportunities. Some TA measures may be delegated to well-qualified QFIs. 
 
A.    Scope 
2.  The scope of the consulting services will be determined in agreement with the targeted 
QFIs and may include the following areas:  
(i)  QFI business strategy development. This will include targeting underserved 
clients,  sectors,  and  regions  and  may  entail  surveys  and  other  appropriate 
mechanisms. 
(ii)  Review and improvement of business processes. Special focus will be on 
lending,  deposit  mobilization,  funding,  human  resources  management,  and 
training. 
(iii)  Risk management and asset liability management functions. This will include 
Basel II and III required management and system capabilities to meet capital 
adequacy. 
(iv)  Product development and marketing campaigns. This will include deposit, 
lending, insurance, and payment service products. 
(v)  Development of responsible finance, environmental, and social safeguards. 
Corporate governance policies and procedures will also be covered. 
(vi)  Regional  seminar.  The  seminar  will  be  held  close  to  TA  completion  to 
disseminate  experiences  among  the  QFIs  and  other  finance  experts  and 
institutions in ADB transition countries.  
 
B.    Expertise 
3.  The required expertise of consultant services (including the distribution of international 
and national experts) will be determined in agreement with the targeted QFIs. All experts will 
have the ability to effectively communicate with clients and their staff to impart analysis, identify 
solutions, and conduct training. Fluency in English is required and Russian is desirable. The 
expertise and consultants required will likely include the following:  
(i)  banking and financial institution leader or consultant with at least 10 years of 
relevant experience, preferably with exposure to transition economies;   
(ii)  banking and financial institution line management function with at least 5 years of 
experience  either  as  head  of  department,  branch manager,  or  business  line 
manager;   
(iii)  banking and financial institution risk management function with at least 10 years 
of experience in a risk department;  
(iv)  treasury and asset liability manager with at least 10 years of experience; and  
                                                
11Armenia,  Azerbaijan,  Georgia,  Kazakhstan,  the  Kyrgyz  Republic,  Mongolia,  Tajikistan,  Turkmenistan  and 
Uzbekistan are eligible target countries.

8  Appendix 3 
 
 
(v)  bank  and  financial  institutions  safeguard  specialists  with  at  least  5  years  of 
relevant experience.
